title: Quiz 3: Puerperium & Postpartum Care
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Postpartum period care including physiological changes, lochia, and maternal recovery

questions.question: What is the definition of the puerperium?

options.text: The period from conception to birth
The period from birth to 6 weeks postpartum
The period from 6 weeks to 6 months postpartum

questions.explanation: The puerperium is defined as the period from the end of the third stage of labour until the involution of the uterus is complete, typically 6 weeks postpartum.
questions.hint: This period covers the postpartum recovery phase.

questions.question: Uterine involution refers to the return of the uterus to its pre-pregnancy size.
questions.explanation: True. Uterine involution is the process by which the uterus returns to its pre-pregnancy size and position. This occurs through contractions and autolysis of uterine muscle fibers.
questions.hint: Think about what happens to the uterus after the baby is born.

questions.question: What is the normal rate of uterine involution?
questions.explanation: The uterus normally involutes at a rate of approximately one fingerbreadth per day. By day 14, the fundus should no longer be palpable abdominally.
questions.hint: This is measured in fingerbreadths when palpating the fundus.

questions.question: Which of the following are types of lochia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The three types of lochia are: lochia rubra (red, days 1-3), lochia serosa (pinkish-brown, days 4-10), and lochia alba (white/yellowish, after day 10).
questions.hint: The names reflect the color changes over time.

questions.question: Match each type of lochia with its correct timing and characteristics:
questions.explanation: Lochia rubra (red) occurs days 1-3, lochia serosa (pinkish-brown) occurs days 4-10, and lochia alba (white/yellowish) occurs after day 10 postpartum.
questions.hint: The progression follows the natural healing process.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ pains are uterine contractions that occur after delivery, typically during breastfeeding.
questions.explanation: Afterpains are uterine contractions that occur after delivery, particularly during breastfeeding. They are more common and intense in multiparas due to increased uterine tone.
questions.hint: These pains are caused by the uterus contracting back to its normal size.

questions.question: When should breastfeeding be initiated after birth?
questions.explanation: Breastfeeding should be initiated within the first hour after birth (the 'golden hour'). This promotes bonding, stimulates milk production, and provides colostrum rich in antibodies.
questions.hint: This is often called the 'golden hour' for breastfeeding.

questions.question: What is the normal amount of lochia in the first 24 hours postpartum?
questions.explanation: The normal amount of lochia in the first 24 hours postpartum is approximately 200-500 ml. Excessive bleeding (>500 ml) indicates postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.hint: Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as blood loss exceeding 500 ml.

questions.question: Lochia that has a foul odor may indicate infection.
questions.explanation: True. Normal lochia has a characteristic fleshy odor similar to menstrual blood. A foul or offensive odor may indicate infection and should be evaluated.
questions.hint: Normal lochia should smell similar to menstrual blood.

questions.question: What is the term for the first breast milk produced after birth, rich in antibodies?
questions.explanation: Colostrum is the first breast milk produced after birth, typically for the first 2-4 days. It is rich in antibodies, protein, and immunoglobulins that provide passive immunity to the newborn.
questions.hint: This milk is often yellowish and very nutritious for the newborn.
